verb.description: Bring one's hand or a tool or weapon into contact with (someone or something) quickly and forcefully.
examples: I hit out with my stick
the woman hit the mugger with her umbrella
use your words, but do not hit

verb.description: (of a missile or a person aiming one) strike (a target)
examples: the sniper fired and hit a third man
the area has been badly hit by business closures

verb.description: Reach (a particular level, point, or figure)
Propel (a ball) with a bat, racket, stick, etc., to score or attempt to score runs or points in a game.

noun.description: An instance of striking or being struck.
examples: few structures can withstand a hit from a speeding car

noun.description: An instance of striking the target aimed at.
examples: one of the bombers had scored a direct hit

noun.description: A successful venture, especially a film, pop record, or song.
examples: he was the director of many big hits

noun.description: A dose of a psychoactive drug.

phrases: The bout turned nasty in the fourth, when Johnson - for the second time in the fight - hit Ruiz below the belt with a hard left hook.
He described Dube as a dirty boxer who was always hitting him below the belt and throwing punches after the bell.
Then Machimane hit Nel below the belt and the fight was temporarily stopped to give the champion time to recover.
If all of them are forced to pay royalty for every song they sing, they will be hit below the belt.
To top it all off, Walter's sudden fierceness hit her below the belt, and her legs suddenly went wobbly with desire.
she hit on a novel idea for fund-raising
The Cigar Club of Ireland has also hit upon a novel form of protest.
One of the leading lubricant-manufacturing companies hit upon a novel idea to attract its customers.
He had hit upon one of the original graves and was too freaked out to go anywhere near the hole.
Once you hit upon the perfect design you can race your creation against competitors from all over the world.
origin: Late Old English hittan (in the sense come upon, find), from Old Norse hitta come upon, meet with, of unknown origin.
